div.p: THE HISTORIE OF THE BIBLE, BRIEFly collected by way of Queſtion and anſvver.

p.hi: Read and corrected by the Author.

q.p: Ye ſhall lay vp theſe my words in your heart & in your ſoule, and bind them for a ſigne vpon your hand, that they may be as a frontlet betweene your eies.
And ye ſhall teach them your children, ſpeaking of them, when thou ſitteſt in thine houſe, and when thou walkeſt by the way, and when thou lieſt downe, and when thou riſeſt vp.
And thou ſhalt write them vpon the poſtes of thine houſe, and vpon thy gates.
That your daies may be multiplied, and the daies of your children, &c.

div.head: To the Chriſtian Reader.
div.p:
CHriſtian Reader, this booke was lately publiſhed in print, and giuen forth to be mine, wherein they haue iniured both thee and me. Thee in publiſhing a Pamphlet ſo faultie and with ſo many wants. The iniurie to me is, becauſe that was giuen forth to be mine, which I did neuer write, nor read ouer written by others, vntill I ſaw it in print. When my children firſt began to ſpeake for the furtherance of them and my ſeruants in the knowledge of the Hiſtorie of the Bible, after a Chapter read at our meales, at dinner out of the old Testament, at ſupper out of the new: I gaue thē by word of mouth onely, ſuch obſeruations as I thought fit for their capacitie & vnderſtanding, and by their anſwers to my queſtions, I daily tooke an account how they vnderſtood and retained the
ſame in memorie. After 26. yeares continuance in this exerciſe, by ſome vnaduiſed youth, or vndiſcreete ſeruant of mine, ſome Printer gate it: wherof whē I had an inckling, I trauelled to ſome in authoritie, and by labouring with them gat it ſtaied not to be printed in Londō: yet it comming forth, they printing it otherwhere without my knowledge or liking: I thought it my dutie beeing thereto intreated alſo by others, to read it ouer, and in ſome ſort to redreſſe the abuſe offered vnto thee by the former Impreſſion. And I beſeech the Lord to bleſſe this and all other my labours in ſome meaſure to be profitable to thee & his church.

closer.dateline: From my houſe at Deptford the 9. of Auguſt. 1602.
closer.signed: The L. vnprofitable Miniſter, lame Euſebius Pagit.

div.head: GENESIS.
div.p: Queſtion.

p.hi: VVHat is Religion?

div.p: Anſwer.
A knitting of vs againe to God.

p.hi: Q. How felt we from God?

div.p: A. By the ſinnes of Adam and Euah.

p.hi: Q. How are we reconc •… vnto God?

div.p: A. By the righteouſnes of Ieſus Chriſt, which is the new and ſecond Adam.

p.hi: Q. Where find you this?

div.p: A. In the Bible.

p.hi: Q. How is the Bible diuided?

div.p: A. Into the old Teſtament and the new.

p.hi: Q. How is the old Teſtament diuided?

div.p:
A. Into the Lawe and the
Prophets.
Q. Who writ the law?
A. Moſes.
Q. In how many bookes?
A. In fiue.

p.hi: Q. What cal you the firſt book?

div.p: A. Geneſis.

p.hi: Q. Why is it ſo called?

div.p: A. Becauſe it containeth the firſt generation of all creatures.
Q. How is Geneſis diuided?
A. Into three parts: the creation of the world: the decay of the world: and the repaire of it againe.
chapter 1 The creation of the world.Q. Who made the world?
A. God.

p.hi: Q. Whereof?

div.p: A. Of nothing.
Q. Wherewith?
A. With his word.

p.hi: Q. In how many daies?

div.p: A. In ſixe.

p.hi:
Q. VVhat did God make the
firſt day?

div.p: A. Heauen, earth, and light.

p.hi: Q. What did he make the ſecond day?

div.p: A. The firmament, and ſeparated the waters.

p.hi: Q. What did he the third day?

div.p: A. He gathered the waters into one place: he made drie land to appeare; he made herbs and trees.

p.hi: Q. What did God make the fourth day?

div.p: A. Sunne, Moone, and ſtarres.

p.hi: Q. What made he the fift day?

div.p: A. Birds and fiſhes.

p.hi: Q. VVhat made he the ſixt day?

div.p: A. Creeping things, beaſts, and Man.

p.label: chapter 2
p.hi: Q. What did God the ſeauenth day?

div.p: A. He reſted and ſanctified it to be a Sabbath.

p.hi: Q. What is a Sabbath?

div.p: A. A reſt.

p.hi: Q. What must we do on the Sabbath day?

div.p: A. Holy things.

p.hi: Q. What are thoſe holy things?

div.p: A. Hearing and learning the word of God preached, praying, receiuing the Sacraments, and meditating vpon Gods creatures.

p.hi: Q. Wherof was Adam made?

div.p: A. Of the duſt of the earth.

p.hi: Q. Wherof was Euah made?

div.p: A. Of the ribbe of Adam.

p.hi: Q. Where were they ſet to dwell?

div.p: A. In the garden of Eden.

p.hi: Q. What were they forbidden to do?

div.p:
A. That they ſhould not eate of the fruite of the tree of
knowledge of good and euil.

p.hi: Q. Did they obey God or not?

div.p: A. No: they did eate of the fruite of the tree of knowledge of good and euill.

p.label: chapter 3
p.hi: Q. What did God with them for breaking his commandement?

div.p: A. He curſed them.

p.hi: Q. Whom did God curſe?

div.p: A. Adam, Euah, and the ſerpent.

p.hi: Q. Why did God curſe the ſerpent, ſeeing the ſerpent did not eate of it?

div.p: A. Becauſe he prouoked thē.

p.hi: Q. Did all the world remaine vnder this curſe or no?

div.p: A. No: God promiſed that the ſeede of the woman ſhould breake the head of the ſerpent.

p.hi: Q. Who was that ſeed of the woman?

div.p: A. Ieſus Chriſt.

p.hi:
Q. What is the efficient cauſe
of mans ſaluation?

div.p: A. The loue of God.

p.hi: Q. What is the materiall cauſe?

div.p: A. The death and paſſion of Ieſus Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. What is the inſtrumentall cauſe?

div.p: A. Faith.

p.hi: Q. What is the finall cauſe?

div.p: A. To glorifie God.

p.hi: Q. How in this world?

div.p: A. By ſeruing him.

p.hi: Q. How in the world to come?

div.p: A. By beeing glorified with him.

p.hi: Q. After that Adam & Euah were accurſed, where were they ſet to dwell?

div.p: A. Abroad in the world.

p.hi: Q. What children had they?

div.p: A. Cain and Abel.

p.hi: Q. How were they brought vp?

div.p: A. In the feare of God.

p.hi: Q. Did they both ſerue God?

div.p: A. Yes.

p.hi: Q. Did they both ſerue God rightly?

div.p: A. No: Cain ſerued God in hypocriſie.

p.hi: Q. What hinderance was there then to religion?

div.p: A. The deuill prouoked Cain to kill his brother Abel.

p.hi: Q. Did Cain kill Abel?

div.p: A. Yes.

p.hi: Q. What did God with Cain for killing his brother?

div.p: A. He curſed him.

p.hi: Q. Did God with this curſe take away all graces from Cain and his posteritie, as well as the graces of adoption?

div.p: A. No: Cain was the firſt builder of cities. Iubal the firſt player of inſtruments. Tubal the firſt inuenter of ſmiths craft. And Iabal the firſt dweller in tents.

p.hi: Q. Cain beeing curſed, and Abel killed, whom did God raiſe vp to ſerue him?

div.p: chapter 5 A. Sheth.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the Fathers before the flood?

div.p: A. Adam, Sheth, Enoſh, Kenan, Mahalaleel, Iered, Henoch, Methuſhelah, Lamech, and Noah.
Q. Who was the oldeſt man that euer liued?
A. Methuſnelah.
Q. How long liued he?
A. Nine hundred ſixtie and nine yeares.

p.hi: Q. What became of Henoch?

div.p: A. He was taken vp both bodie and ſoule to walke with God.
Q. How many were ſo taken vp beſide him?
A. Two: Eliah, and Ieſus Chriſt.

p.hi: Q. In what time were theſe taken vp?

div.p: A. Henoch, before the law: Eliah, in the law: and Ieſus Chriſt in the Goſpell.

p.hi: Q. Why were they thus takē vp?

div.p: A. That they might be three figures of our reſurrection, that we ſhall riſe againe both body and ſoule to walke with God.
chapter 6 Q. Did religion continue in the poſteritie of Sheth?
Q. In whoſe daies decayed it?
A. In the daies of Enoch.

p.hi: Q. What ſigne or ſhew was there of the decay of religion?

div.p: A. When the ſonnes of God ſaw that the daughters of men were faire, they tooke thē wiues of whom ſoeuer they liked.
Q. Who were the ſons of God?
A. The poſterity of Sheth.

Q. Who were theſe daughters
of men?
A. The poſterity of Cain.

p.hi: Q. What fruit came of theſe marriages?

div.p: A. Gyants, monſtrous men in conditions.
Q. What did God with the world beeing thus repleniſhed?
A. He drowned it.
Q. Was all the world drowned?
A. No.

p.hi: Q. Who were ſaued?

div.p: A. Noan, 〈◊〉 , his ſons, and their wiues.
Q. Wherein were they preſerued?
A. In the Arke.
Q. Did the Arke preſerue thē?
A. No, God did ſhut it.
Q. How long rained it?
A. Fourtie daies and fourty nights.

p.hi: Q. How long did the waters preuaile vpon the face of the earth?

div.p: A. One hundred and fiftie daies.
chapter 8 Q. When the waters were decreaſed, what meſſengers did Noah ſend foorth?
A. A Rauen and a Doue.

p.hi: Q. Whether brought the better newes?

div.p: A. The Doue brought an Oliue leafe in her mouth.

p.hi: Q. When the waters were gone, did Noah come forth of the Arke?

div.p: A. No: he tarried ſeauen daies: for he ſaid, as he went in at Gods commandement, ſo he would come forth.
Q. When God commaunded him to come forth, what was the firſt thing he did?
A. He offered ſacrifice vnto God.

p.hi: Q. Did God accept his ſacrifice?

div.p: A. Yes.
Q. How know you?
A. Becauſe he promiſed that he would neuer drown the world againe.
chapter 7 The repaire of the world.Q. What aſſurance gaue God of this promiſe?
A. He ſealed it vp with the figne of the Rainebow.

p.hi: Q. What did Noah after this?

div.p: A. He planted a vineyard and was drunke.
Q. What did his ſonnes vnto him in his drunkenneſſe?
A. Ham made a mocke at his fathers nakednes: Shem and Iapheth took a garment & couered their fathers nakednes.

p.hi: Q. What ſaid Noah when hee awoke and knew what his ſons had done vnto him?

div.p: A. He ſaid, Curſed be Ham, and bleſſed be Shem and Iapheth.

p.hi: Q. What nations came of theſe three ſonnes of Noah?

div.p: A. Of Shem, came the Iſraelites. Of Ham, came the Cananites. Of Iapheth came the Centiles.

p.label: chapter 11
p.hi: Q. Did the poſteritie of the world take any warning by the flood or not?

div.p: A. No: they built them a citie and a tower that ſhould reach vp to heauen.
Q. Who was the chiefe in this building?
A. Nimrod, a mightie hunter and ſpoiler of men.
Q. What did they ſeeke in their building?
A. A name, and that they might not be ſcattered vpon the face of the earth.
Q. Did God like of their building?
A. No: he ſcattered them vpon the face of the earth, and confounded their language.

p.hi: Q. What name got they?

div.p: A. Babel, which is confuſiō.

p.hi: Q. They being thus ſcattered, what became of them?

div.p: A. The tenth chapter ſheweth the places and countries where they dwelt, ſome cities which they built, and the people which came of them.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe the fathers after the flood?

div.p: A. Shem, Arpachſhad, Shelah, Eber, Peleg, Reu, Serug, Nahor, Terah, and Abraham.

p.label: chapter 12
p.hi: Q. After the confuſion of languages, whom did God raiſe vp to ſerue him.

div.p: A. Abraham.

p.hi: Q. Whence had he him?

div.p: A. Out of the land of Vr.

p.hi: Q. Whither had he him?

div.p: A. Into the land of Canaan.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe Abrahams iourneyes?

div.p:
A. Haran, Haai, Egypt, Bethel:
the vale of Mamre. Gerar, Moriah, and Hebron.

p.hi: Q. What was the firſt thing that Abraham did when he came to any place?

div.p: A. He ſought a place to ſerue God in.

p.hi: Q. What befel to him at Harā?

div.p: A. He loytered by the way, and his father Terah died.
Q. What befell to Abraham at Haai?
A. There was a famine.

p.hi: Q. Whither went he to dwell thē?

div.p: A. Into the land of Egypt.

p.hi: Q. What befell to him there?

div.p: A. His wife was taken away by proud king Pharaoh.

p.hi: Q. Did Pharaoh commit wickedneſſe with her?

div.p: A. No: the Lord would not ſuffer him.

p.hi: Q. Had Abraham his wife againe?

div.p: A. Yes.
Q. Whither went he then?
A. To Bethel.

p.hi: Q. What befell there?

div.p: A. There was a quarrel betweene Abrahams ſeruants & Lots.

p.hi: Q. How was the quarrell ended?

div.p: A. Abraham ſaid to Lot, If thou wilt go on the left hand, I will go on the right: or, if thou wilt go on the right hand, I will go on the left.
Q. Whither went Lot then?
A. To Sodome.

p.hi: Q. What manner of place was Sodome?

div.p: A. A pleaſant place, but the people were wicked.
Q. Whither went Abraham then?
chapter 14 A. To the plaine of Mamre.

p.hi:
Q. What befell to Lot for
dwelling in ſuch a wicked place among ſo wicked people?

div.p: A. He was taken priſoner by foure kings.
Q. Did he continue priſoner?
A. No: the Lord deliuered him by the hand of Abraham.
Q. When Abraham came frō the battell, who met him?
A. Melchizedeck king of Salem, and the king of Sodom.

p.hi: Q. Why came Melchizedeck?

div.p: A. To bring bread & wine for Abrahams armie.

p.hi: Q. Why came the king of Sodome?

div.p: chapter 15 A. For his men againe.

p.hi: Q. Abraham hauing ouercome the foure kings, and fearing leaſt the whole countrie would riſe vp againſt him, how did God comfort him?

div.p: A. He promiſed him a ſonne.

Q. How would Sarah Abrahams
wife haue this promiſe performed?
chapter 16 A. By a handmaid, named Hagar.
Q. Had Araham a ſonne by her?
A. Yes.

p.hi: Q. What was his name?

div.p: A. Iſhmael.
Q. Did God like this deuiſe of Sarah, that ſhee would haue his promiſe performed by ſinne?
A. No: ſhee was the firſt that ſinarted for it: for ſhee was deſpiſed of her maid Hagar.

p.hi: Q. Theſe troubles beeing in Abrahams houſe, how was his faith ſtreng thened?

div.p: chapter 17 A. God promiſed him a ſonne by his wife Sarah.

p.hi: Q. What aſſurance gaue he of this promiſe?

div.p: A. He ſealed it vp with the Sacrament of circumciſion.
Q. Did the Sodomites continue in their wickedneſſe?
chapter 18 A. Yes: they waxed worſe and worſe.

p.hi: Q. What did the Lord then?

div.p: A. He came downe to ſee their wickedneſſe, and reuealed vnto Abraham the deſtruction thereof.

p.hi: Q. What did Abraham?

div.p: A. He prayed for them.

p.hi: Q. What ſaid the Lord?

div.p: A. He ſaid he would ſpare thē, if there were only ten righteous perſons found in Sodom.

p.hi: Q. What did the Lord when he could not finde tenne righteous perſons in that ſinfull citie?

div.p: chapter 19 A. He ſent downe fire and brimſtone from heauen and conſumed them.

p.hi: Q. Were all the inhabitants of Sodome defiroyed.

div.p:
A. No: Lot, his wife, and
his two daughters were preſerued.

p.hi: Q. What became of his ſonnes in law?

div.p: They were deſtroyed with the reſt of the city, be cauſe they made a mocke at their fathers warning.

p.hi: Q. What became of Lots wife?

div.p: A. Shee looked backe, and was turned into a pillar of ſalt.

p.hi: Q. Whather wont Lot to dwell then?

div.p: A. To a litle citie called Zoar.
Q. Whither went he thence?
A. Into the mountaines.

p.hi: Q. What befell to him there?

div.p: A. His two daughters made him drunke, and lay with him.

p.hi: Q. What fruite came of that inceſtuous act?

div.p:
A. There were two childrē borne, Moab, and Ben-ammi, the fathers of two curſed nations,
the Moabites, & the Ammonites.

p.hi: Q. In the euening before Sodome was deſtroyed, how did it appeare vnto Abraham?

div.p: A. Like a paradiſe of God.

p.hi: Q. How did it appeare in the next morning?

div.p: A. Like the ſmoke of a furnace, verſ. 28.

p.label: chapter 20
p.hi: Q. Whither went Abraham to dwell then?

div.p: A. To the land of Gerar.

p.hi: Q. What befell to him there?

div.p: A. His wile was taken away by king Abimclech.

p.hi: Q. Did he commit wickednes with her?

div.p: A. No, the Lord would not ſuffer him.

p.hi: Q. Had Abraham his wife againe?

div.p: A. Yes.

p.hi:
Q. Had he a ſonne according
to promiſe?

div.p: A. Yes.

p.hi: Q. How called he his name?

div.p: A. Iſaac.

p.hi: Q. VVho nurced him?

div.p: A. His mother Sarah.
Q. What did Abraham when he was weaned?
A. He made a feaſt.

p.hi: Q. What befell at the feaſt?

div.p: A. Iſhmael mocked Iſaac.
Q. What befell to Iſhmael for mocking Iſaac?
A. He and his mother were baniſhed.
chapter 22 Q. How did God prooue Abrahams faith?
A. He bad him offer his ſonne Iſaac in ſacrifice.

p.hi: Q. Did he offer him?

div.p: A. Yes.
Q. Did he kill him?

A. No: the Angell of the Lord appeared vnto him and
ſaid, Abraham, Abraham, ſtay thy hand.

p.hi: Q. What did Abraham then offer in ſtead of his ſonne?

div.p: A. A Ram, which was tyed by the hornes in a buſh.
Q. Where was it that Abraham did offer his ſonne?
A. At Moriah.
Q. What poſſeſſion did Abraham buy in the land of Canaan?
A. He bought a field to burie his dead in.

p.hi: Q. Whom did he burie there?

div.p: A. His wife Sarah.
Q. How long liued ſhe?
A. One hundred twenty & ſeuen yeares.
Q. How was Iſaac brought vp?
A. In the feare of God.

p.hi: Q. How was he married forth?

div.p: A. To a woman named Rebecca.

p.label: chapter 25
p.hi: Q. Had Abrahā another wife?

div.p: A. Yea, Keturah.

p.hi: Q. How many children had he by her?

div.p: A. Sixe ſonnes.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe their names.

div.p: A. Zimran, Iockſhan, Medan, Midian, Iſhback, and Shuah.

p.hi: Q. Had theſe any inheritance with Iſaac?

div.p: A. No: he gaue all his goods to Iſaac, and gaue gifts to his other ſonnes, & ſent them away into the Eaſt frō his ſon Iſaac.

p.hi: Q. How long liued Abraham?

div.p: A. One hundred ſcuentie and fiue yeares.

p.hi: Q. Where was Abraham buried?

div.p: A. His two Sonnes Iſaac & Iſmael buried him in the caue of Machpelah by his wife Sarah

p.hi: Q. Had Iſaac any children by Rebecca?

div.p: A. Yes: 2. ſons, Eſau & Iacob.

p.hi: Q. Whether of them was the elder?

div.p: A. Eſau.
Q. How loſt he his birthright?
A. He ſold it to Iacob for a meſſe of pottage.
Q. What befell in the daies of Iſaac?
chapter 26 A. There was a famine.

p.hi: Q. Whether went he then?

div.p: A. Into the land of Gerar.
Q. What befell to him there?
A. The Lord appeared vuto him, and promiſed to giue the land of Canaan to his ſeede.
Q. What befell there more?
A. He denied his wife: the Lord made him to proſper, in ſo much that the inhabitants of the countrie ennied him and ſlopped his wels.
Q. Whether went he then?
A. To Beer-ſheba.

p.hi: Q. What befell there?

div.p:
A. The Lord appeared vnto
to him and comfort him.
Q. What was the firſt thing he did there?
A. He offered facrifice vnto God.

p.hi: Q. Whilſt he was there who came vnto him?

div.p: A. Abimelech, Abuzzath, & Pichol the chiefe captaine of his armie.
Q. Wherefore came they?
A. To make a league with them.

p.hi: Q. How did Eſau looſe the bleſſing?

div.p: chapter 27 A. Iacob came firſt, and brought kids dreſſed like veniſon, and ſaid that he was his firſt borne, and ſo got the bleſſing.

p.hi: Q. What ſaid Eſau when Iacob had goiten both birth-right and bloſſing from him?

div.p:
A. He ſaid, The daies of
mourning for my father will come ſhortly, then wil I ſlay my brother Iacob.

p.hi: Q. To preuent this, whither did Iſaac & Rebecca ſend Iacob?

div.p: chapter 28 A. To Padan Aram to marrie a wife.

p.hi: Q. What company had he?

div.p: A. His ſtaffe in his hand.

p.hi: Q. What lodging had he that night?

div.p: A. Hee laid him downe on the ground, and a ſtone vnder his head.
Q. What appeared to him there?
A. A ladder ſtanding at his head, the top whereof reached vp to heauen, the Angels of God went vp and downe by it, and God aboue it.

p.hi: Q. Who was that ladder?

div.p: A. Ieſus Chriſt, who is the way, the truth, and the life, Ioh. 4
Q. What did he learne thereby?
A. That the angels of the Lord were continually ready to bring downe comfort and ſuccour to the faithfull: but to the wicked, plagues and puniſhments.
Q. What did he in the morning?

A. He tooke the ſtone and ſet it vp as a pillar, & powred oyle on it, and ſaid: if God will bee with me, and keepe me in this lourney, which I goe, and giue me bread to eate, & cloathes to put on; ſo that I may returne to my fathers houſe in ſafety, then ſhall the Lord bee my God, and this ſtone ſhal be his houſe, and I will come and ſerue him heere.
Q. Did the Lord prosper his iourney?
chapters 25,30 A. Yes: for he had wiues, children, and ſubſtance.
Q. How many wiues had hee?
A. Two: Leah and Rahel.

p.hi: Q. How many children had he in Padan Aram?

div.p: A. Eleuen ſonnes and one daughter.
Q. Rehearſe their names?
A. Reuben, Simeon, Leui, Iuda, Iſſachar, Zebulon, Dan, Gad, Aſher, Nepthali, Ioſeph, and Dinah, his daughter.
Q VVhat ſubſtance had hee?
A. Hee had men ſeruants, maid ſeruants, flocks oſſheepe, heards of cattel, & great riches.

p.hi: Q. How long ſerued he in Padan Aram?

div.p: chapter 30 A. Twentie yeares: viz. ſeauen yeres for Leah; ſeuen yeres for Rahel; & ſixe for his riches.
Q. VVhy did hee not remaine with Laban?

A. Becauſe the Lord commanded him to returne into his
countrey.

p.hi: Q. When he returned, with whom had he controuerſie?

div.p: A. With Laban, with God, and with his brother Eſau.
Q. How was the controuerſie ended with Laban?
A. God charged Laban in a dreame that he ſhouldſpeake nothing but good to Iacob.

p.hi: Q. How was the controuerſie endedwith God?

div.p: A. He wreſtled with God, who gaue him a pinch in the thigh, that he halted euer after; but he left not wreſtling vntill he obtained the bleſſing.

p.hi: Q. How was the controuerſie ended with Eſau?

div.p: A. With faire words.
Q. Whither went Iacob then?

chapters 33,34 A. Vnto Sechem: and there he bought a parcell of ground of Hamor Shechems father, for
an hundred pieces of ſiluer.

p.hi: Q. Why went he not to Bethel according to the vow and promiſe he had made?

div.p: A. He was ſo rich he had forgotten his promiſe made when he was poore.

p.hi: Q. How did God puniſh him?

div.p: A. His daughter Dinah was rauiſhed: Simeon and Leui became murtherers, and he ſtanke before all the countrey.
Q. Whither went he then?
chapter 35 A. To Bethel.
Q. What charge gaue he vnto his houſhold?
A. He charged them to put away their ſtraunge gods, to clenſe their hearts, and change their garments.

p.hi: Q. What did the Lord for the confirmation and ſtrengthning of his faith?

div.p:
A. He changed his name
from Iacob to Iſrael. ch. 32.28.
Q. What befell as hee parted from Bethel?
A. Rahel died in childbirth.
Q. What called ſhee the childs name?
A. Ben-oni: the ſonne of mine affliction.

p.hi: Q. What did his fathers call him?

div.p: A. Beniamin.

p.hi: Q. Whether went he then?

div.p: A. Beyond Migdal-eder.

p.hi: Q. What befell to him there?

div.p: A. Beuben lay with his fathers concubine.
Q. How old was Iſaac when he died?
A. One hundred and foureſcore yeares.
Q. Who buried him?
A. His two ſonnes Eſau and Iacob.
Q. Where went Iacob when his father Iſane died?
chapter 17 A. In the land of Canaan.

p.hi: Q. What befell to Ioſeph?

div.p: A. His brethren hated him: becauſe his father loued him beſt; becauſe of his dreames, & becauſe he told his father of their euill ſayings.
Q. What would they haue done with him?
A. They would haue killed him.
Q. Who ſaued him?
A. Ruben and Iudah ſaid vnto the reſt, he is our brother, let vs not ſhed his blood.
Q. What did they with him?
A. They put him in a pit.
Q. What did they then?
A. They made a feaſt.
Q. Were all preſent at the feaſt?
A. No: Ruben was abſent.
Q. What did they then with Ioſeph.
A. They ſold him to the Iſhmalitiſh marchants for twentie peeces of ſiluer.

p.hi: Q. When Reuben came to the pitte and found not Ioſeph there, what did he?

div.p: A. He rent his cloathes, and went to his brethren, and ſaid, The childe is not yonder, and I, whither ſhall I goe?

p.hi: Q. What did the Iſomalitiſh marchants with him?

div.p: A. They carried him into Egypt, and ſold him to Potiphar an cunuch of Pharaohs.
Q. Who was Iudah his wife?
chapter 38 A. The daughter of Shuah a Cananite.
Q. How many ſonnes had he by her?
A. Three: Er, Onan, and Shelah.
Q. What became of Er, & Onan?

A. The Lord ſlewe them
becauſe of their wickedneſſe.
Q. What is ſet downe of Iudah?
A. He lay with Thamar his daughter in law.
Q. What ſaid Iudah when it was told him that Thamar his daughter in lawe had plaied the harlot and was with child?
A. He had them bring her forth and burne her.
Q. What learne you from hence?
A. That the law which was written in mans heart, taught them that who redome ſhould be puniſhed with death: for as yet the law was not giuen.

p.hi: Q. When Potithar had brought Ioſeph into Egypt, what did hee with him?

div.p: A. He made him ruler ouer his houſe.

p.hi: Q. What did he with him afterward?

div.p: A. He put him in priſon becauſe his wife ſlandered him, & ſaid that he would haue lien with her.
Q. What did Ioſeph beeing in priſon?
chapter 40 A. He receiued mercie at the hands of the Lord, & found fauour at the maſter of the priſō.
Q. What is ſet downe beſides whileſt he continued in priſon?
A. He expounded the chiefe butlers & chiefe bakers dreams, beeing priſoners with him.

p.hi: Q. Who then deliuered Ioſeph out of priſon?

div.p: chapter 41 A. Pharaoh; becauſe he expounded his dreames.
Q. What did Pharaoh with him after this?

A. He made him ruler ouer all Egypt, taking the ring from his owne finger, and putting it on Ioſephs, he arraied Ioſeph
in garments of fine linnen, and put a golden chaine about his necke.
Q. When Ioſeph was ruler ouer Egypt what did he?
A. He gathered corne, in the ſeauen years of plentie, to ſerue in the ſeauen yeares of famine, according to the interpretation of Pharaohs dreames.
Q. What hapned then?
chapter 42 A. The famine was ſo great in the land of Canaan, that Iacob was enforced to ſend his ſonnes into Egypt for corne.

p.hi: Q. Did Ioſeph know his brethren?

div.p: A. Yes.

p.hi: Q. How did he vſe them?

div.p: A. Roughly both in word and deed, for he called them ſpies, he accuſed them of theft, he impriſoned them, and ſent them for Beniamin.
Q. Did he this of malice, becauſe they had vſed him ſo cruelly?
A. No; he did it to trie their repentance for their former ſins, and their loue to their brother Beniamin.
Q. How aften came Ioſephs brethren?
chapter 45 A. Twiſe.

p.hi: Q. Came Beniamin?

div.p: A. Yes.
Q. What reaſon had Ioſeph to trie their loue towards Beniamin, rather then to any of the reſt?
A. Becauſe Rahel had no more children but himſelfe and Beniamin.
Q. What did Ioſeph after this?
chapter 46 A. He made himſelfe known vnto his brethren, and fent for his father.

Q. How long was it from that time that he was ſold by his brethren,
vntill the time that he made himſelfe knowne vnto them?
A. It was 22. yeares: at 17. he was ſold: at 30. he ſtood before Pharaoh: then ſeauen years of plentie were paſt, & in the ſecond yeare of the famine he made himſelfe knowne.
Q. Came Iacob?
A. Yes.

p.hi: Q. How many ſoules came with Iacob into Egypt?

div.p: chapter 47 A. Seauentie.
Q. What ſaid Ioſeph vnto Pharaoh concerning his father and his brethren?
A. He ſaid they were poore Shepheards in the land of Canaan.
Q. How old was Iacob then?
A. One hundreth and thirtie yeares.

p.hi: Q. Where dwelt Iacob then?

div.p: A. In the land of Goſhen.

p.hi: Q. When Iacob was ſicke who came to viſite him?

div.p: chapter 48 A. Ioſeph with his two ſons Manaſſeth and Ephraim.
Q. What ſaid Iacob to Ioſeph?
A. Hee commanded and made him to ſweare that hee would carrie him out of Egypt, and burie him in the land of Canaan.

p.hi: Q. How long lined Iacob in Egypt?

div.p: A. Seuenteene yeares, and 130. before: in all he liued 147. yeares.
Q. Did Iacob make a will before his death?
A. Yes.
Q. To whome gaue he the kingdome?
A. To Iudah; becauſe Reuben lay with his fathers concubine, and Simcon and Leui had bloodie hands.
Q. Who had the Prieſthood?
A. Leui.

p.hi: Q. How fell it out that he had the prieſthood?

div.p: A. Becauſe his hands were ſanctified with the ſlaughter of the idolaters. Exod. 32.28.
Q. Who had the double portion?
A. Ioſeph, becauſe he had more afflictions, then his brethren.
Q. How many things did belong to Reuben as to the elder?
A. Three: the kingdome: the prieſt-hood: and the double portion.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe Iacobs twelue ſons?

div.p: A. They were rehearſed before all ſauing Beniamin.
Q. Rehearſe the twelue tribes?

A. Reuben, Simeon, Iudah, Iſſachar, Zebulon, Dan, Gad, Aſher, Nepthali, Beniamin,
Ephraim, and Maneſſeth.

p.hi: Q. Which of Iacobs ſonnes are left forth?

div.p: A. Leui and Ioſeph: Leui, becauſe he had bloodie hands; and Ioſeph, becauſe he had the double portion, more afflictions then his brethren.

p.hi: Q. Whowere placed in their ſtead?

div.p: A. Ephraim and Manaſſeth.
Q. What armes did Iacob giue vnto his ſonnes?
A. Ruben water.
Simeon and Leui, inſtruments of crueltie.
Iudah, a Lyon.
Iſſachar, an aſſe.
Zabulon, a hauen for ſhips.
Dan, a Serpent.
Gad, an hoaſt of men.
Aſher, dainties for a King.
Nepthali, a hinde.
Ioſeph, a fruitefull bough ouer a wall.
Beniamin, a wolfe.
Q. When Iacob died where was he buried?
chapter 50 A. In the caue of Machpelaph, which Abraham bought of Ephron the Hittite.

p.hi: Q. Why was he buried in the land of Canaan?

div.p: A. That it might be a ſigne to his poſteritie, that they ſhould returne into the land of Canaan.

p.hi: Q. How long did Ioſeph beare rule ouer the land of Egypt?

div.p: A. Foureſcore yeares.

p.hi: Q. How long liued he in all?

div.p: A. One hundred and tenne yeares.

p.hi: Q. When he died where was he buried?

div.p: A. He was embalmed to be carried into the land of Canaan at his brethrens returne.

div.head: Exodus.

p.hi: Q. VVhat call you the ſecond booke of Moſes?

div.p: A. Exodus.

p.hi: Q. Ʋ Ʋhy is it ſo called?

div.p: A. Becauſe it containeth the going of the children of Iſrael out of the land of Egypt.

p.hi: Q. VVhat is the ſubſtance of this booke?

div.p: A. The eſtate of the children of Iſrael from the death of Ioſeph, vntill the eſtabliſhing of the Tabernacle in the wilderneſſe.

p.hi: Q. Into how many parts is it deuided?

div.p: A. Into two parts: part 1 Their eſtate in the Land of Egypt after the death of Ioſeph vntill their departure: part 2 and their eſtate in the wildernes vntill the eſtabliſhing of the Tabernacle.

p.hi: Q. How were the children of Iſrael vſed after the death of Ioſeth?

div.p: A. They had burdens and afflictions laid vpon them.
chapter 1 Q. Were they overwhelmed with theſe burthens?
A. No: the more they were afflicted, the mightier they grew.
Q. What lawes did Pharaoh make againſt them?
A. That the midwiues ſhould flay their men children: afterward he commanded them to be caſt into the riuer.
Q. Did the Midwiues obey the King?
A. No.
Q. Did they well in diſobeying him?
A. Yes: becauſe he commanded them an euill worke.
Q. Did the Lord like it?
A. Yes: for he built their houſes and bleſſed them.
Q. Theſe lawes beeing made, how eſcaped Moſes?
chapter 2 A. His mother hidde him three moneths, and when ſhe could hide him no longer, ſhee made a basket of reedes, ſhme and pitch, and laid him among the bulruſhes, by the riuers ſide.

p.hi: Q. How eſcaped he drowning?

div.p: A. Pharaohs daughter came to waſh her ſelf, and found him there.

p.hi: Q. What did ſhe with him?

div.p: A. She put him to nurſe to his owne mother.

p.hi: Q. What did his mother when ſhe had weined him?

div.p: A. She brought him to Pharaohs daughter againe.
Q. What did ſhee with him?
A. She brought him vp in Pharaohs court.
Q. What was the cauſe of his departure from the court?
A. Pharaoh would haue killed him, becauſe he had ſlaine an Egyptian, and buried him in the lands.
Q. How long liued Moſes in Pharaohs court?
A. Fourtie yeares.
Q. Whither went he then?
A. Into Midian.

p.hi: Q. What did he there?

div.p: A. He kept Iethros ſheepe, and married Zipporah his daughter.
Q. Had Moſes, any children by her?
A. Yes: a ſonne called Gerſhom.

p.hi: Q. What befell to him then in Midian?

div.p:
chapter 3 A. The Lord appeared in a flame of fire out of a buſh, and bad him goe and deliuer his
brethren the children of Iſrael out of Egypt.
Q. Was he willing to goe?
A. No: for he propounded fiue obiections.
1. Firſt his owne baſeneſſe.
2. Secondly, his ignorance of Gods name.
3. Thirdly, that they would not heare him.
4. Fourthly, his ſlow ſpeech.
5. Fiftly, he deſired him to ſend another.
Q. How did the Lord anſwer them?
A. To the firſt he ſaid: I will be with thee.
2. Secondly, he told him his name.
3. Thirdly, he gaue him ſignes.
4. Fourthly, he ſaid I will bee with thy mouth, and teach thee what to ſay.
5. He was angrie.

p.label: chapter 4
p.hi: Q. What ſignes did God giue Moſes to aſſure him, that he beeing a poore ſhepheard ſhould deliuer them out of the hands of ſo mighty a king?

div.p: A. Firſt, he bad him caſt his rod on the ground, and it was turned into a ſerpent, and hee bad him take it by the tayle, and it was turned into a rodde againe.
Secondly, he bad him put his hand into his boſome, & it was leaprous, and he bad him pull it out againe, and it was as his other hand.
Thirdly, he bad him take water and ſprinkle it on the ground, and it was turned into blood.
Q. Whom did God ſend with Moſes to helpe him?
A. Aaron his brother.

p.hi: Q. Did he then goe?

div.p: A. Yes.

p.hi: Q. Who met him by the way?

div.p: A. The Angel of the Lord, who would baue ſlaine him, becauſe he neglected the circumciſion of his ſonne.

p.hi: Q. Who did circumciſe him?

div.p: A. His mother Zipporah tooke a ſharpe knife and cutte the fore-skinne of her ſonne, & caſt it at her husbands feet, ſaying, thou art indeede a bloodie husband vnto me.

p.hi: Q. VVho met him then?

div.p: A. Aaron his brother.

p.hi: Q. Did they their meſſage vnto Pharaoh?

div.p: A. Yes.

p.label: chapter 5
p.hi: Q. VVould Phraoh let the people goe?

div.p:
A. No: hee ſaid, who is the Lord that I ſhould obey him?
〈◊〉 people are
〈◊〉 .

p.hi: Q. What commandement gaue he then?

div.p: chapter 6 A. He commaunded them to make the whole tale of brick, & to gather ſtraw themſelues.
Q. What did the people then?
A. They murmured againſt Moſes and Aaron.

p.hi: Q. What did Moſes?

div.p: A. He complained vnto the Lord.
Q. What did the Lord then?
A. He renueth his promiſe concerning their deliuerance & ſendeth Moſes and Aaron againe vnto Pharaoh.

p.hi: Q. Did Pharaoh then let them goe?

div.p: chapter 7 A. No: the Lord had hardned his heart, and he would not let them goe.
Q. Did Moſes and Aaron their miracles before Pharaoh?
A. Yes.
Q. Why then would he not let them go?
A. Becauſe his Sorcerers did the like.
Q. How many plagues did God ſend vpon Pharach and the Egyptians before he would let them goe?
A. Tenne.

p.label: chapter 8
p.hi: Q. Rehearſe them?

div.p: A. He turned water into blood, fiſhes died.
2 Frogges ouer the land of Egypt.
3 Lyce.
4 Swarmes of Flies.
5 Murraine amongſt beaſts.
chapter 9 6 Scabs and bliſters.
7 Thunder, lightning, and haile.
chapter 10 8 Graſhoppers.
9 Darkneſſe.
chapter 11 10. All the firſt borne of Egypt were ſlaine.

p.hi: Q. Did the Sorcerers of Egypt the like?

div.p: A. Yes, vntill lice; then they ſaid, Surely it is the finger of God.

p.hi: Q. Would Pharaoh then let them goe?

div.p: A. Yes, at darkneſſe, all ſauing their cattell.

p.hi: Q. What ſaid Moſes?

div.p: A. He ſaid he would not leaue a hoofe behind him.

p.hi: Q. Did any of theſe plagues hurt the Iſraelites?

div.p: A. No.

p.hi: Q. What did they at their departure?

div.p: A. They borrowed of their neighbours the Egyptians, iewels of ſiluer, & iewels of gold.

p.hi: Q. What aſſurance did God giue them that the laſt and greateſt plague ſhould not hurt the Iſraelites?

div.p: chapter 12 A. He inſtituted the Paſſeouer.
Q. What was the Paſſe-ouer?
A. A male lambe of a yeere old, without ſpot or blemiſh.

p.hi: Q. How ſhould it be dreſſed?

div.p: A. They ſhould roaſt it.
Q. How ſhould it be eaten?
A. With their loines girded, their ſhooes on their feet, their ſtaues in their hands readie for a iourney, and they muſt eate it in haſt.

p.hi: Q. What ſhould be done with the blood?

div.p: A. They ſhould ſtrike it on their doore poſts, that the Angell ſeeing it, might paſſe ouer them.

p.hi: Did he let them goe at the laſt plague?

div.p: A. Yes.
Q. How many were they that departed?
A. About ſixe hundred thouſand men beſides children.
Q. How long were they in Egypt?
A. Foure hundred and thirtie yeares.

p.hi: Q. What did the Iſraelites the?

div.p:
chapter
A. They ſanctified all their firſt borne vnto the Lord.

p.hi: Q. What did they at their departure?

div.p: A. They tooke the bones of Ioſeph with them.

p.hi: Q. How many yeares were they going out of Egypt into Canaan?

div.p: A. Fourtie yeares.

p.hi: Q. How many iourneys had they?

div.p: A. Fourty and two.

p.hi: Q. How many principall iourneys?

div.p:
A. Twelue: Piha-hiroth, Marah, the wilderneſſe of Sin, Rephidim, mount Si •… i, Kibroth, Hetaauah, Hazeroth, Rithmah in Parā, Cadeſh barnea,
Mount Hor, Punā in Zalmonie, and the plaine of Moab.
Q. How many of them are ſet downe in this booke?
A. The firſt fiue, Piha-hiroth, Marah, the wilderneſſe of Sin, Rephidim, and mount Sinai.
Q. How were they conducted into the land of Canaan?
A. The Lord went before them by day in a pillar of a cloud to leade them the way, & by night in a pillar of fire to giue thē light, that they might goe both by day and by night. chap. 13. verſ. 21.

p.hi: Q. What befell at Pi-hahiroth?

div.p: chapter 14 A. They murmured againſt Moſes, becauſe the redde ſea was before thē the mountaines on either ſide of them, & Pharaoh with all his hoaſt behind them.

p.hi: Q. What did Meſes?

div.p: A. He prayed vnto the Lord, and the Lord bad him ſtrike the fea with his rodde; and he did ſo: and the ſea was deuided, ſo that the children of Iſrael paſſed through drie-ſhod: But Pharaoh and all his hoaſt following them, were drowned.

p.hi: Q. What did the children of Iſrael then?

div.p: chapter 15 A. They ſang a ſong of thankſ-giuing for their deliuerance.
Q. Whether went they then?
A. To Marah.

p.hi: Q. What befell there?

div.p: A. They murmured againſt Moſes, becauſe the waters were bitter.

p.hi: Q. What did Moſes?

div.p:
A. He prayed vnto the Lord, and the Lord badde him
cut downe boughes, & caft the into the waters, and they were made ſweet.

p.hi: Q. Whither went they then?

div.p: A. To Elim, where were 12. fountaines of water, and ſeuentie palme trees.

p.hi: Q. Whither went they then?

div.p: chapter 16 A. To the wilderneſſe of Sin.

p.hi: Q. What befell there?

div.p: A. They murmured againſt Moſes and Aaron for bread, and the Lord ſend them downe Manna.

p.hi: Q. What did they elſe?

div.p: A. They ſanctified the ſabbath.

p.hi: Q. What did Moſes command them?

div.p: A. To keepe a pot full of Manna, for a remembrance to their poſternie.
Q. How long did they eat Māna?

A. Fourtie yeares, till they
came to the borders of Canaan.

p.hi: Q. VVhither went they then?

div.p: A. To Rephidim.

p.hi: Q. What did they there?

div.p: chapter 17 A. They murmured againſt Moſes for water; and the Lord bad him ſtrike the rocke, and there guſhed out water.

p.hi: Q. What befell there elſe?

div.p: A. They fought a battel with the Amalekits, and builded an altar.
Q. Who had the victorie?
A. When Moſes held vp his hands, Iſrael preuailed, but when he held them down, the Amalekits ouercame.
Q. What beſell after this?
chapter 18 A. Iethro Moſes father in lawe came to ſee him, and gaue him counſell for the chooſing of Magiſtrates.
Q. What maner of men ought they to be?
A. Men of courage, fearing God, hating couetouſnes, and louing the truth.
Q. What muſt theſe Magiſtrates doe?
A. They muſt bring the hard cauſes vnto Moſes, and iudge ſmall matters themſelues.
Q. Whither went they then?
A. To Mount Sinai.
Q. What befell there?
chapter 19 A. Iſrael is choſen from among all other nations: The people promiſed to obey God: He that toucheth the hil dieth: The Lord appeared vnto Moſes, and gaue the law in thunder and lightening.
Q. Why was the lawe ſo giuen?
A. That it might compell them to obey and follow it with feare and trembling.

Q. Why was the Gospell giuen
in triumph and ioy?
A. That it might entice men to follow it ioyfully and willingly.
Q. In how many tables was the law giuen?
A. In two tables of ſtone.
Q. Why were they written in ſtone?
A. Becauſe it was more eaſie to write them in ſtone then in mans heart.
Q. How many commandements doth the firſt table containe?
chapter 20 A. Foure; wherein is ſet downe our dutie towards God.

p.hi: Q. How many commandements doth the ſecond table containe?

div.p: A. Sixe; wherein is ſet down our dutie towards our neighbour.
Q. Who writ this law?
A. God.

Q. Were there no more lawes
nen but the ten commandements?
A. Yes, but thoſe are the ſumme of all: for there were iudiciall and ceremoniall lawes giuen alſo.
Q. VVhat did the 21. chap. containe?
A. Certaine lawes for the preſeruation of mans bodie, which were giuen to bridle our corrupt nature.
Q. What doth the 22. cha. containe?
A. Certaine iudiciall lawes concerning buying and ſelling, vſurie, reuerence to Magiſtrates, &c.
Q. What doth the 23. chapt. containe?
A. Certaine ceremoniall lawes of feaſts.

p.hi: Q. What did the Lord promiſe them that would obey and keepe his commandements?

div.p: A. He ſaid, I will be an enemie to thine enemies, and I will afflict them that afflict thee, &c. verſ. 22.23.
Q. What doth the 24. chap. containe?
A. The confirmation of the law.

p.hi: Q. How long was Moſes in the Mount?

div.p: A. Fourtie daies and fortie nights.

p.hi: Q. How many things did the Lord appoint Moſes to make?

div.p: A. Nine.

p.hi: Q. Which be they?

div.p: chapter 25 A. 1. The Tabernacle. 2. Arke. 3. Mercie feate. 4. Table of ſhewbread. 5. Candleſticke. 6. Altar of burnt offering. 7. Altar of perfume. 8. Lauar. 9. Prieſts garments.

p.hi: Q. Who ſhould make them?

div.p: chapter 31 A. Aholiab and Bezaleel,

p.hi: Q. Whereof ſhould they make them?

div.p: A. Of thoſe things which the people brought, viz. of gold, ſiluer, braſſe, blew ſilke, purple, skarlet, fine linnē, goates haire, rammes skins died redde, badgers skinnes, and Shittim wood.

p.hi: Q. Whileſt Moſes was in the Mount, what did the people?

div.p: chapter 32 A. They made a Calfe and worſhipped it.

p.hi: Q. What did the Lord then?

div.p: A. He bad Moſes go down to them.
Q. What did he when he came downe?

A. He caſt the two tables out of his hands, & brake them beneath the Mount, and hee tooke the Calfe, and burned it in the fire, and grounded it vnto powder, and ſtrewed it vpon
the water, and made the children of Iſrael to drinke of it.
Q. What did Moſes then?
A. He went and ſtood in the gate of the camp, and ſaid, who pertaineth to the Lord, let him come to me.
Q. Who came then vnto him?
A. The Leuites.

p.hi: Q. What ſaid he to them?

div.p: A. Put euery man his ſword by his ſide, and go to and fro from gate to gate through the hoaſt, and ſlay euery man his brother, and euery man his cō panion, & euery man his neighbour: and they did ſo; for which their hands were ſanctified.

p.hi: Q. How many were ſlaine that day?

div.p: A. About 3. thouſand men.
Q. What befell after this?
A. The Lord was angry & denied to go with them.

p.hi: Q. What did Moſes then?

div.p: A. He prayed vnto the Lord, and he promiſed to goe with them.
Q. What did Moſes elſe?
A. He deſired to ſee the glorie of the Lord.

p.hi: Q. Did the Lord graunt his requeſt?

div.p: A. Yes: for he couered him in the cleft of a rocke whilſt he paſſed by.

p.hi: Q. What did the Lord after this?

div.p: A. He bad Moſes hew two tables of ſtone like to the former, and to come vp to the top of the Mount.
Q. Did he ſo?
A. Yes.

p.hi: Q. How long ſtayed he in the mount?

div.p: A. Fourty daies and fourty nights.

Q. Whence ſhould they haue
their prouiſion to make thoſe things which were appointed?
A. From the people.

p.label: chapter 33
p.hi: Q. Did they bring enough?

div.p: A. Yes, they brought ſo much, that they were bidden to ſtay.

div.head: LEVIT.

p.hi: Q. What call you the third booke of Moſes?

div.p: A. Leuiticus.
Q. Why is it called ſo?
A. Becauſe it containeth the office of the Leuites, and thoſe things which appertaine vnto them.

p.hi: Q. How is it diuided?

div.p: A. Into two parts: the ſacrifice which they were to offer, and the perſons which ſhould offer.

p.hi:
Q. By whome was this lawe
of ſacrifices giuen?

div.p: A. By the Lord.

p.hi: Q. Where?

div.p: A. In the tabernacle by Mount Sinai.

p.hi: Q. How many kinds of ſacrifices were appointed?

div.p: A. Fiue: the offering, chap. 1. the meat-offering, cha. 2. the peace-offering, cha. 3. the ſinne-offering, chap. 4. the treſpaſſe-offering, chap. 5.

p.hi: Q. How many things are to be obſerued in theſe ſacrifices?

div.p: A. Two: the matter or things wherof they were, & the maner how they ſhould be offered.

p.hi: Q. What manner of things were appointed to be offered?

div.p: A. They were of two ſorts, either of creatures which haue life; or of creatures without life.

p.hi:
Q. What things are appointed
which haue life?

div.p: A. Of the heard, bullockes, a red cow: of the flocke, rams, ewes, lambes, goates, both male and female. Of foules, Turtle doues, pigeons, and ſparrowes.

p.hi: Q. What are thoſe things without life?

div.p: A. Oyle, fine floure, incenſe, cakes, and wafers vnleauened, ſalt, eares of corn, Cedar wood, a skarlet lace, and hyſope.
Q. In offering of ſacrifices what is forbidden?
A. Leauen, hony, fat, blood, the inwards of beaſts, and the maw of birds.
Q. What is thereby figured?
A. By leauen and hony, corruption of doctrine and life: by fat and blood are figured, ſenſualitie and crueltie.

p.hi:
Q. What things are principally
commanded to be vſed in the ſacrifices?

div.p: A. Salt, and fire, the one eating away, and the other purging corruptions.

p.hi: Q. Thus much of the matter, now of the manner and rites to be obſerued in offering the ſacrifice, what they were?

div.p: A. They were diuerſe, and are ſet downe in diuerſe places of this booke, but eſpecially in the 6. and 7. chapters.
Q. Now we are come to the ſecond part of the booke, which concerneth the perſons of the Leuites and ſacrificers, what doth the holy Ghoſt ſet downe concerning them?
A. Two things: the firſt is ſpeciall to them alone: the ſecond is common to them with others, namely, ſanctification.

Q. What is that which is proper
to them alone?
A. ſo offer the ſacrifices which was appointed to Aaron & his ſonnes: their conſecration, and the execution of their function, chap. 8.9.

p.hi: Q. VVith what fire?

div.p: A. With ſuch fire as came from the Lord.
Q. Did any offer with other fire?
A. Yes, Nadab and Abihu, for which, fire came frō before the Lord and conſumed them, chap. 10.
Q. VVhat is that which is common to the Leunes with the reſt of the people?
A. Sanctification, and that is preſcribed firſt, in forbidding that which is euill: ſecondly, in commanding that which is good.
Q. VVhat are thoſe things forbidden?
A. They are either ceremoniall or morall.
Q. What are the lawes ceremoniall?

A The diſtinction of creatures cleane or vncleane, chap. 11. touching of things accounted vncleane, vncleaneſſe after child-birth, chap. 12. or for certaine diſeaſes of the body, cha. 13.14. and 15. and purification from vncleanneſſe, chap. 16. and 17.
Q. What are thoſe morall things forbidden?
A. Adulterie, fornication, inceſt, and all ſuch vncleannes chap. 18. and in part of the 20, and 21. chap.
Q. Now to come to things which are commanded, what are they?

A. They are either priuate to our ſelues; or in performance of our dutie to our neigbour,
or elſe to God, as followet •… the reſidue of the booke.
Q. What times or feaſts are principally appointed?

A. The times and feaſtes appointed in this booke, are either weekely, as the Sabbath, or yearely as the paſſeouer, the feaſt of vnleauened bread, of the firſt fruites of Whitſontide, of trumpets, and of Tabernacles.
Q. Is there no other time appointed for the ſeruice of God but theſe?
A. Yes, he hath appointed to be ſerued euery day with a morning and euening ſacrifice, Numb. 28.4.

p.hi: Q. How did Moſes conclude this booke?

div.p:
A. He ſealed vp theſe former lawes with the promiſes and threatnings of God. Chap.
26. and the laſt chapter concerneth vowes.

div.head: Numbers.

p.hi: Q. What call you the fourth booke of Moſes?

div.p: A. Numbers.
Q. Why is it ſo called?
A. Becauſe it principally conſiſteth of numbring.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of it?

div.p: A. The hiſtorie of the children of Iſrael after their departure from Mount Sinai, vntill they came to the plaine of Moab, vpon the confines and borders of the land of Canaan.

p.hi: Q. How is this booke deuided?

div.p:
A. Into two parts: the firſt containeth the numbring of the children of Iſrael, prepared for the iourney: the ſecond, the number of their iourneyes
from Mount Sinai to the borders of Canaan, and at their laſt ſtation they are again numbred.

p.hi: Q. What was the number of the people here numbred?

div.p: A. Sixe hundred and three thouſand, fiue hundred and fiftie.
Q. How often were the children of Iſrael numbred in this their trauell?
A. Thrice, the firſt and ſecond times at Mount Sinai, the third at their laſt ſtation, when they were to enter into the land.

p.hi: Q. Why were they thus often numbred?

div.p: A. The firſt time they were nūbred, that towards the building of the tabernacle, euery man might giue a price for the redemption of his life.

The ſecond time they were
numbred for diſpoſing of thē in order for iourneying about the Tabernacle, and pitching their tents at the end of their iourney.
The third time they were numbred, that the diuiſion and diſpoſing of the land might be to euery tribe according to the number.
Q. Why were the Leuites numbred the firſt time?
A. To ſhew that they haue need of a redeemer, & redemption as well as any other men.

p.hi: Q. Why were not the Leuites nū bred the ſecond nor third time?

div.p: A. They were not numbred the ſecond time, becauſe they were to attend vpon the tabernacle, and not to go to warre.

And they were not numbred the third time, becauſe they had no lot of inheritance amōg
their brethren.

p.hi: Q. At what age were the Leuites taken to the Lord?

div.p: A. At a moneth old they were dedicated to the Lord, Num. 3.15. at 28. they were to labour and to do ſeruice in the tabernacle, Num. 8.28. at thirtie to enter into the more inward works of the Sanctuary, Numb. 4.3. and at fiftie to leaue the hard labours, and to take charge to guide, to ouer-ſee, & to preſcribe by counſell and inſtruction what others ſhould do. Num. 8. • .5.

p.hi: Q. How many of the twelue principall iourneys are ſet downe in this booke?

div.p: A. Seauen: Kibroth Hattavah, Hazeroth, Rithma in Paran, Kadeſh-Barnea, Mount Hor, Punon in Zalmona, and the plaine of Moab.
Q. How many things do you obſerue in theſe iourneys?
A. Two: either ſuch as are common to them all, or peculiar to either, ſeuerally conſidered by it ſelfe.
Q. How many things are there cōmon to euery of theſe iourneys?
A. Three: the peoples murmuring, Moſes prayer, & Gods mercies.

p.hi: Q. Did the people murmure at euery iourney?

div.p: A. Yes, in ſeauen iourneyes they murmured eight times.
Q. Againſt whom did they murmure?
A. Vpon euery diſlike they did murmure againſt Moſes & againſt God.

p.hi: Q. What did Moſes when they murmured at him?

div.p:
A. Hee as a moſt mild man prayed, yet once hee ſhewed a
paſſion of imperfection, for which the Lord was angrie, and would not ſfufer him to enter into the land of Canaan. chap. 20.11.

p.hi: Q. Did the Lord beare with their continuall grudgings and murmurings?

div.p: A. Yes, he gaue eare to Moſes prayers, and continued his mercies towards them.

p.hi: Q. Now ſhew me thoſe things which are peculiar to each iourney: and firſt to Kibroth Hattavah?

div.p: A. Firſt, as wearie of their iourney, they murmured. The Lord ſent fire and conſumed the vtmoſt parts, but Moſes praying, the fire was quenched.

Secondly, they loathed Manna the heauenly bread: luſted for fleſh: 70. Elders are ioyned to Moſes to aſſiſt him in gouerning
this vnruly people: Quailes are ſent, and the people die with the fleſh betweene their teeth. chap. 11.

p.hi: Q. What is peculiar to the ſtation at Hazeroth?

div.p: A. Aaron and Miriam murmured againſt Moſes.

p.hi: Q. For what cauſe?

div.p: A. They pretended one cauſe, his matriage with a Midianitiſh woman, but their ambition was the very cauſe, chap. 12.2. Miriam is ſtriken with leproſie: Moſes praieth and God healeth her.

p.hi: Q. What is peculiar to Rithma in Paran?

div.p:
A. Twelue men are ſent to ſearch the land of Canaan. Vpon the falſe report of tenne the people murmure, as if God could not performe his promiſe to giue them the Land.
They would haue ſtoned Caleb and Ioſhua for reporting the truth.
Q. How were they deliuered from ſtoning?

A. By the hand of the Lord: who told them that none of thē ſhould enter into the land of promiſe, ſaue Caleb & Ioſhua: and they which enterpriſed to enter into the land contrarie to Gods appointment, are ſlaine by their enemies.
Q. Did the people remayning, (taſting his mercies and ſeeing his iudgements) loue, feare, and ſerue him?
A. No: there was one found vpon the Sabbath day gathering of ſticks.

p.hi: Q. What was done with him?

div.p: A. He was by the Lords commādement ſtoned to death chap. 15.36.
Q. That was but the act of one, what did the reſt?
A. Others did not take heede, for firſt Korah, Dathan, Abiram, and On, with 250. captaines rebelled againſt Moſes and Aaron, and the earth opening, ſwallowed vp them and theirs.
Secondly, the people not taking warning thereby, did all murmure againſt Moſes & Aaron, wherefore there were deſtroyed, 14700. of them.
Q. What did Moſes and Aaron?
A. They ſought an attonement with God for them.
Q. How was the matter ended?
A. God ſet order, firſt, for the Prieſthood, ſecondly, for a ſacrifice for their ſinnes.

Q. What order was taken for
the Prieſthood?

A. The Lord bad Moſes take for euery tribe a rod, and write euery mans name vpon their rodde, and Aarons name vpon Leuies rod, and lay them in the tabernacle before the arke, and the mans rod which budded would the Lord chuſe.
Q. Whoſe rod did bud?
A. Aarons did budde and bloſſome, and he had the prieſthood.
Q. What order was taken for their ſinnes?
A. God appointed the ſacrifice of the red cow, chap. 19. for the cleanſing of theſe their ſinnes, and the aſnes of purifying of the vnclean by touching the dead.

p.hi: Q. When they departed from Rithma in Paran, whither went they?

div.p: A. To Kadeſh-Barnea.

p.hi: Q. What things are peculiar to that iourney?

div.p: A. Foure: firſt, the death of Miriam.
Secondly, the Iſraelites murmure for water.
Thirdly, Moſes and Aaron are charged with incredulitie, and receiue iudgement to dy in the wilderneſſe.
Fourthly, Edom denieth Iſrael paſſage through his country.
Q. The next iourney beeing Mount Hor, what befell there?
A. Aaron dieth: Eleazer his ſonne ſucceedeth him. Arad the King of Canaan commeth forth againſt Iſrael and is vanquiſhed.
Q. To their iourney frō mount Hor, to Punon in Zalmona, what things are peculiar?

A. In their iourney about
the land of Edom, they murmure at the hardneſſe of the way, and for bread and water loathing Manna.
They are deſtroyed by fierie ſerpents, and are remedied by the brazen ſerpent.
They ouerthrow two kings, Sihon and Og, & deſtroy their countries.

p.hi: Q. In their iourney to the plain of Moab, what is principally to be conſidered?

div.p: A. The eſtate of them, when ſome of them entred into their portions, and others were readie to enter.
Q. How many things are herein to be conſidered?
A. Two: firſt, the hinderances, ſecondly, the reconciliation of the people.
Q. How were they hindred?

A. Partly by others, but eſpecially
ſpecially by their owne ſinnes.

p.hi: Q. Who were thoſe others?

div.p: A. Balak the king of Moab, who ſent for Balaam to curſe the people. Balaam the falſe Prophet, who could not curſe them, but gaue counſell to allure them to ſinne: and the Midianitiſh women, who enticed them to fornication and idolatrie.

p.hi: Q. Did the Lord ſuffer theſe ſinnes to go vnpuniſhed?

div.p: A. No: he began firſt with his owne people, & by a plague deſtroyed of them 24000.

p.hi: Q. What did he with his enemies?

div.p: A. When he was reconciled to his people, he powred out his wrath vpon them.

p.hi: Q. In what ſort?

div.p:
A. Balakand the 5. Kings of Midian were ſlaine. Balaam
the falſe Prophet was controlled by his aſſe, and alſo ſlaine. All the males of Midian, and the women who had lyen by man, were ſlaine.

p.hi: Q. How was God reconciled to his people?

div.p: A. By the zeale of Phineas, who ſlew Zimri and Cosbi committing fornication.
Q. What teſtimonie did God giue of his reconciliation?

A. Firſt, he made a couenant with Phineas. Secondly, he appointed Ioſhua to be gouernour in Moſes ſtead. Thirdly, he gaue to Reuben, Gad, and halfe the tribe of Manaſſeth, their portions on that ſide of Iordan in the Land of Moab. Fourthly, twelue men are aſſigned to deuide the land of Canaan. Laſtly, their lawes giuen for ſacrifices, obſeruation of
feaſts, vowes, cities of refuge, and inheritances.

div.head: Deuteron.
div.p: Q. VVhat call you the fifth booke of Moſes?
A. Deuteronomie.
Q. VVhy is it ſo called?
A. Becauſe it containeth a ſecond reherſall of the law.
Q. VVhat doth he in the beginning of this booke?

A. He repeateth the actes which God had done for them in peace and warre: becauſe they were dead to whom the Law was giuen in mount Sinai: and to make them more attentiue to the lawe, from the firſt chapter to the fift.
Q. VVhat doth he then?

A. He repeateth the lawe more particularly, he exhorteth
and perſwadeth them to obſerue and keepe the Lawe, from the 5. chap. to the 31. In the 31. Chapter he prepareth himſelfe to die, and reſigneth vp his office.
In the 32. chap. he ſingeth a Pſalme: and in the 33. chap. he bleſſeth the Tribes of Iſrael.
Q. Why did Moſes bleſſe Leui otherwiſe then Iacob did?
A. Becauſe of the zeale that the Leuites ſhewed at Mount Sinai, the curſes of Iacob vpon Leui, were turned into bleſſings.
Q. Where died Moſes?
A. In the land of Moab.
Q. Why did he not enter into the land of Canaan?

A. Becauſe he murmured at the waters of Miribah, ſaying: Heare now ye rebels: ſhall wee giue you water out of the
rocke? Numb. 20.10.

p.hi: Q. Did he ſee the land of Canaan?

div.p: A. Yes, he went vp into mount Nebo, vnto the toppe of Piſgah, and the Lord ſhewed him all the land of Gilead vnto Dan.

p.hi: Q. Vhom did he appoint in his ſtead?

div.p: A. Ioſhua the ſonne of Nun?

p.hi: Q. How long liued Moſes?

div.p: A. One hundred and twentie yeares.
Q. Where was he buried?
A. In a valley in the Land of Moab, ouer againſt Bethpeor, but no man knoweth of his ſepulchre vnto this day.
Q. By whom was he buried?
A. By an angel of the Lord: leaſt the Iſraelites knowing of his graue, ſhould go a whoring after it.

div.head: IOSHVA.
div.p: Q. What gouernour had the children of Iſrael after they came out of Egypt?
A. Captaines.
Q. How many captaines had they?
A. Two: Moſes and Ioſhua.
Q. What did Moſes?
A. He brought them out of Egypt into the wilderneſſe.

p.hi: Q. What did Ioſhua?

div.p: A. He brought them out of the wilderneſſe into the land of Canaan.

p.hi: Q. What called you this booke?

div.p: A. Ioſhua.

p.hi: Q. Why is it ſo called?

div.p: A. Becauſe it containeth the gouernment of Ioſhua.

p.hi: Q. What is the ſubſtance of this booke?

div.p:
A. The eſtate of the children
of Iſrael after the death of Moſes, til they were eſtabliſhed in the land of Canaan.
Q. How many things muſt we conſider in this booke?
A. Three, Ioſhua his calling, his acts, and his death.

p.hi: Q. Who called him?

div.p: chapter 1 A. God.

p.hi: Q. What to do?

div.p: A. To gouerne his people.
Q. What charge gaue he him?
A. To do all things which he commanded, and only thoſe.
Q. Did he ſo?
A. Yes.
Q. How did God bleſſe them?

A.
chapter 2 The people obeyed him.
chapter 3 They paſſed Iordan dri-ſhod.
chapter 4 The people beeing ſore with circumciſiō, their enemies durſt not ſtirre againſt them.
chapter 5 The wals of Iericho fell downe, no man touching them.
Q. How are his acts diuided?
A. Into his acts of warre, and his acts of peace.
chapter 2 Q. What were his acts of war?
A. He ſent out two men to ſpie Iericho, and as they were ſpying, the men of the citie ſought to kill them.

p.hi: Q. How eſcaped they?

div.p: A. By the meanes of an harlot named Rahab.

p.hi: Q. When they departed what did they?

div.p: A. She made them ſweare that they would ſpare her and all her houſhold at the deſtruſtruction of the citie.

p.hi: Q. How did they get out of the citie?

div.p: A. She let them downe by a cord through a window.
Q. What ſigne did they giue her of her deliuerance?

A. They bidde her bind a
cord of red threed in the window, through which ſhee let them downe.
Q. Whither went they then?
A. They returned to Ioſhua.
Q. What newes brought they?
A. That all the inhabitants of the Land fainted becauſe of Iſrael.
Q. What did Ioſhua then?
chapter 4 A. Hee bad them ſet vp 12. ſtones in Iordan, and as many in Gilgal, for a memoriall to their poſteritie.
Q. What did the Lord then?
A. He commanded Ioſhua to circumciſe euery man childe of the children of Iſrael.

p.hi: Q. What did Ioſhua then?

div.p:
chapter 5 A. Hee made him ſharpe kniues as he was commaunded, and circumciſed all the men children that were borne in the
wildernes ſince their comming out of Egypt, for they did not circumciſe any by the way.

p.hi: Q. Where were the children of Iſrael when they were circumciſed?

div.p: A. At Gilgal.
Q. What befell there elſe?
A. Manna ceaſed, and they did eate of the fruite of the land of Canaan.
Q. What Did Ioſhua then?
chapter 6 A. He ouerthrewe Iericho, and burnt it with fire, onely the gold and ſiluer, with braſſe and yron, were conſecrated to the Lord.

p.hi: Q. After what manner was Iericho taken?

div.p:
A. The arke of God compaſſed it ſixe daies, euery day once, and the ſeauenth day the Prieſts carried it about the citie ſeauen times, and the men of
warre went before the arke, & all the hoaſt followed, & when they had compaſſed the citie ſeauen times, and the Prieſts had blowne with their trumpers of Rammes hornes ſeauen times, the people ſhouted with a loud voice, & then the walles of the citie fell down flatte, and they went vp into the citie, and ſlew the inhabitants with the edge of the ſword.

p.hi: Q. Were all the inhabitants destroycd?

div.p: A. No: Rahab, her father, mother, and children, with all that ſhe had were preſerued.

p.hi: Q. Whither went they then?

div.p: chapter 7 A. Ioſhua ſent three thouſand men to take Ai.

p.hi: Q. Did they take it?

div.p: A. No: for the men of Ai ſlew 36. of them, and put the reſt to flight.

p.hi: Q. What was the cauſe they ſlew them and put them to flight?

div.p: A. Becauſe Achan tooke of the Excommunicate things, therefore the Lord was angrie, and ſuffered their men not to haue the victorie.

p.hi: Q. What had he taken?

div.p: A. A Babiloniſh garment, 200. ſhekels of ſiluer, and a wedge of gold of 50. ſhekels weight.

p.hi: Q. How was he puniſhed for it?

div.p: A. All the children of Iſrael ſtoned him to death.

p.hi: Q. What did Ioſhua then?

div.p: chapter 8 A. He went to Ai, and tooke all the men of warre with him.

p.hi: Q. What did he when he came thither?

div.p:
A. He ſent 500. men to lie in wait on the back ſide of the citie, and hee and all the reſt
of the people came before the citie.
Q. What did Ioſhua and his people in the battell?
A. They fled before them as they did at firſt, which they perceiuing came all out of the citie and purſued.
Q. What did Ioſhua then?

A. He ſtretched out his ſpeare that was in his hand towards Ai, according as he had giuen notice to them that lay on the backe-ſide of the citie, and they aroſe and came to the citie & ſet it on fire: and when the men of the citie looked backe and ſawe their citie on fire, they were greatly afraid: then Ioſhua and the children of Iſrael which fledde, returned and ſlewe the men of Ai. Alſo the other iſſued out of the citie againſt them on
the other ſide, and let none of them eſcape.
Q. What was the number of thoſe that were ſlaine?
A. Twelue thouſand, euen all the men of Ai.
Q. What did he with the cattell and ſpoyle thereof?
A. They tooke it to themfelues for a pray.
Q. What did Ioſhua then to the citie?
A. He burnt it, & made it an heape for euer, and a wilderneſſe to this daie.

p.hi: Q. What did he with the king thereof?

div.p: A. He hanged him on a tree.
Q. VVhat did Ioſhuah then?
A. Hee built an altar to the Lord, and wrote a rehearſall of the Law, and read it in the preſence of all the children of Iſrael.
Q. What befell then?
chapter 9 A. Many kings aſſembled together to fight againſt Ioſhua.

p.hi: Q. Did none of the inhabitants of the land make peace with them?

div.p: A. Yes: the Gibeonites.

p.hi: Q. What did they?

div.p: A. They tooke old bottles and wine, and mouldie bread, and put on old ſhooes, and old raiment, and came to Ioſhua, and ſaid, they were come from a far countrie to make a league with them, and Ioſhua made a league with them.

p.hi: Q. What did Ioſhua when he knew their craft?

div.p: A. He commanded them to perpetuall ſlauerie.

p.hi:
Q. What did the fiue kings of the Amorites when they heard that the Gibeonites had made a
league with them?

div.p: chapter 10 A. They gathered themſelues together and made war againſt them.

p.hi: Q. What did the Gibeonites?

div.p: A. They ſent to Ioſhua to pray him to come and deliuer them.
Q. What did Ioſhua?
A. He aſcended from Gilgal all that night, and all the men of war with him, & came vpon them ſuddenly, and diſcomfited them, and they fledde towards Bethoron.

p.hi: Q. What did the Lord then?

div.p: A. He did caſt downe great ſtones vpon them from heauen vntill Azekah, and there were more ſlain with hailſtones then with the ſword.

p.hi: Q. What did Ioſhua then?

div.p:
A. He badde the Sun ſtand
ſtill in Gibeon, and the Moone in the valley of Ailon vntil they had auenged thēſelues on their enemies, and that was the longeſt day that euer was.
Q. What became of the fiue kings of the Amorites?
A. They fledde to Makkedah and hid themſelues in a caue.
Q. What did Ioſhuah when he knew it?

A. He bad men roule great ſtones to the mouth of the Caue, and he ſet men to keepe them, and hee bad the reſt followe after their enemies, and not ſuffer them to enter into their cities, and they ſmote them with an exceeding great ſlaughter: then they returned to Gilgal.
Q. What was done when they returned?
A. The fiue Kings were brought out of the caue.
Q. What did Ioſhua to them?

A. Hee commaunded his chiefe men of warre to come and ſet their feete vpon them, and they did ſo: Afterwards hee ſlewe them, and hanged them on fiue ſeuerall trees vntill the Sunne went downe, then hee tooke them downe, and caſt them into the caue, and laid greate ſtones vpon the caues mouth, which remaine till this day.
Q. What did Ioſhua then?
A. Hee ouercame many cities, and deſtroyed three kings more, and he ſlew the inhabitants, thē he returned to Gilgal.

p.hi: Q. What did the reſt of the kings when they heard of this?

div.p:
A. They gathered themſelues together, and came and
pitched at the waters of Merom to fight againſt Iſrael.

p.hi: Q. What did the Lord then?

div.p: A. He bad Ioſhua not bee afraid of them, hee would deliuer them all ſlaine before him, and he ſhould hough their horſes and burne their Chariots with fire.

p.hi: Q. VVhat did Ioſhua then?

div.p: A. He and all the men of war came ſuddenly out and ſmote them, vntill there were none of them remaining.

p.hi: Q. Did Ioſhua deſtroy their cities?

div.p: A. No, he deſtroyed none of the cities ſaue onely Hazor: which he burnt with fire, but he houghed their horſes, and Surnt their chariots with fire, as the Lord had told him.

p.hi: Q. Did the inhabitants of Canaan make peace with the Children of Iſrael & the Gibeonites?

div.p: A. No.
Q. Why did they not make peace with them?
A. Becauſe the Lord hardened their hearts to the end they ſhould come to battell againſt the children of Iſrael, and they might vtterly deſtroy them.

p.hi: Q. What did Ioſhua then?

div.p: A. He deſtroyed the Anakims out of the land of Iſrael, onely in Azzah, Gath, and Aſndod they were left.

p.hi: Q. How many kingdomes did the children of Iſrael ouercome in all?

div.p: chapter 12 A. Thirtie and one.

p.hi: Q. When the children of Iſrael had ouercome their enemies, what did Ioſhua?

div.p:
chapters 13,14,&c. A. He denided the land by lots: he appointed cities of refuge: he gaue cities to Leuites.
He ſent back Ruben, Gad, and halfe the tribe of Manaſſes.
Q. VVhat did Ioſhua at his death?
chapter 13 A. He gathered the children of Iſrael together, and exhorted them not to ioyne with the Gentiles, vowing that whatſoeuer they did, he & his houſe would ſerue the Lord.
Q. What became of Ioſhua then?
A. He died.

p.hi: Q. How old was he when he died?

div.p: A. One hundred and tenne yeares.

div.head: IVDGES.
div.p: Q. After the death of Ioſhua what gouernement had the children of Iſrael?
A. Iudges.
Q. What is the ſubſtance of this booke?
A. The eſtate of the children of Iſrael in the land of Canaan, after the death of Ioſhua.

p.hi: Q. How is it deuided?

div.p: A. Into three parts: their ſinnes; their oppreſſours; and their deliuerers.
Q. What were their ſinnes?
A. Contempt of religion, Idolatrie, theft, and whoredome.
Q. Who were their oppreſſours?
A. The Aramites, Philiſtims, Midianites, Moabites, Cananites, and Ammonites.

p.hi: Q. How long were they oppreſſed?

div.p: A. One hundred and eleuen yeare.

p.hi: Q. What did they beeing oppreſſed?

div.p: A. They cried vnto the Lord, and he ſent them deliuerers.

p.hi: Q. Rehearſe their names?

div.p: A. Otheniel, Ehud, Shamgar, Deborah, Barack, Gedeon, Abimeleck, Tola, Iaer, Iptah, Ibſau, Elon, Abdon, Sampſon, Eli, and Samuel.

p.hi: Q. How many yeares did God giue them Iudges?

div.p: A. Three hundred & thirtie nine yeares vntill Samuel.
Q. Why then doth Paul in the thirteenth of the Acts ſay, that God gaue them Iudges 450. yeares?
A. He reckeneth the Iudges and oppreſſours together whoſe yeares added together make 450.
Q. Out of whoſe hands did Otheniel deliuer them?
A. The Aramites, ch. 3.10.
Q. Out of whoſe hands did Ehud deliuer them?
A. The Moabites.

p.hi: Q. Out of whoſe handes did Shamgar deliuer them?

div.p: A. The Philiſtims.

p.hi: Q. Out of whoſe hands did Dehora and Barack deliuer them?

div.p: A. The Cananites, chap. 4.

p.hi: Q. Out of whoſe hands did Gideon deliuer them?

div.p: A. The Midianites, chap. 6.7.8.
Q. What is recorded of Abimeleck?
A. He vſurped the kingdom, and ſlue 70. of his brethren vpō a ſtone, chap. 9.

p.hi: Q. What befell to him then?

div.p: A. A woman with a peece of a milſtone brake his brainepanne.
Q. What did he then?

A. He commanded his page,
his armour-bearer to thruſt him through, that it might not bee ſaide that a woman had killed him.

p.hi: Q. What is recorded of Tola and laer?

div.p: A. There is no mention of any notable acts done by them, cap. 10.

p.hi: Q. Out of whoſe handes did Iphtah deliuer them?

div.p: A. The Ammorites: he offered his daughter in ſacrifice to God, and ouercame 42000. Ephramites. cap. 11.12.

p.hi: Q. What did Ibſan, Elon, and Abdon?

div.p: A. They gouerned quietly.

p.hi: Q. Out of whoſe handes did Sampſon deliuer them?

div.p: A. The Philiſtims. ca. 13.14.
Q. Rehearſe Sampſons acts?

A. He ſlue a Lyon, hee ſlue 30. Philiſtims for 30. charge
of garmēts: he burnt their corn: he ſlue four thouſand men with the iaw bone of anaſſe: he carried away the gates of Azzah: he ſlew moe at his death, then he did in all his life.
Q. By what ſmall meanes did God bring theſe things to paſſe?

A. Ehud beeing lame of his right hand, ſlue Eglon the fatte King with a Dagger of a cubit long. Shamgar ſlue fixe hundred Philiſtims with an Oxe goad: Iael a woman killed Siſera with a hammer and a pin: Gedeon ouercame an hoaſt of men with broken Pot-ſheardes and Rams hornes. There is no mention made of Eli and Samuel in this booke, but in the booke of Samuel.

div.head: Ruth.

p.hi: Q. What call you the next booke?

div.p: A Ruth.

p.hi: Q. Why is it ſo called?

div.p: A. Becauſe ſhe is the perſon that is principally handled there.

p.hi: Q. How is it deuided?

div.p: A. Into two parts: Naomies and Ruths afflictions, and their proſperitie.

p.hi: Q. Of what countrie was Ruth?

div.p: chapter 1 A. Of Moab.
Q. Who was her huſband?
A. Chilion of Bethlem in Iudah.
Q. How came he into Moab?

A. There was a famine in Iſrael, and ſo his father Elimeleck tooke his two ſons, Mahlon and Chilion, and Naomie his wife, and went and ſoiourned
in the countrie of Moab, where Elimeleck died: then his ſonnes took them wiues, the name of Mahlons wife was Orpah, and the name of Chilions wife was Ruth.

p.hi: Q. What befell to them in the land of Moab?

div.p: A. Elimeleck and his two ſonnes died.

p.hi: Q. What did Naomie then?

div.p: A. She returned into the land of Iudah.

p.hi: Q. Why did ſhe returne?

div.p: A. Becauſe ſhe heard ſay that the Lord had viſited her people in plentie and giuen them bread.
Q. What companie had ſhe with her?
A. Her two daughters in law, Orpah and Ruth, but Orpah went back againe.

Q. Why did not Ruth returne
with her ſiſter?
A. Shee would not leaue her mother in law, but ſaid, Whither thou goeſt thither wil I go, and where thou dwelleſt, there will I dwell; thy people ſhal be my people, and thy God my God.
chapter 5 Q. How did God bleſſe her?
A. Shee was married to a rich man named Booz: of him came Chriſt.

div.head: 1. SAMVEL.
div.p: Q. What doe you call the next booke?
A. Samuel.
Q. How many things muſt we conſider in this booke?
Q. Two: the gouernment of the two laſt Iudges, and the two firſt Kings.

p.hi:
Q. Which are the Iudges which
are mentioned in this booke?

div.p: A. Eli and Samuel.

p.hi: Q. How are the acts of Eli deuided?

div.p: A. Into his good and bad acts.

p.hi: Q. What were his good acts?

div.p: A. His diligēce in his calling.
Q. What were his bad acts?
A. His negligence in not looking to his ſonnes, and not correcting them, chap. 2.
Q. How was hee puniſhed for his negligence?
A. The Arke of God was taken: his two ſonnes Hophni and Phineas were both ſlaine in one day: he hearing of it, fell downe backward and brake his necke. chap. 4.

p.hi: Q. What became of his daughter in law?

div.p:
A. Shee died in child-birth, for ſhee ſaid, the glorie is departed
from Iſrael.

p.hi: Q. What became of the Arkthen?

div.p: A. The Philiſtims brought it to Aſhdod, and ſet in the houſe of Dagon their god.

p.hi: Q. How were they plagued?

div.p: A. Dagon fell downe before the arke of God, his head and the palmes of his hands were broken, and the inhabitants were ſmittē with emrods.
Q. What did they with the arke of God?
A. They carried it to Gath.
Q. Did it continue there?
chapter 6 A. No: for the Lord ſmote them with Emrods, and they caried it to Ekron, and the Ekronites were ſmitten with Emrods alſo.
Q. How long did the Philiſtems keepe the arke?
A. Seauen moneths.

p.hi:
Q. What did they then with
the arke?

div.p: A. They ſent it home with gifts.

p.hi: Q. What were the gifts which they ſent with it?

div.p: A. Fiue golden Emrods, & fiue golden Mice.

p.hi: Q. How did they ſend the arke home?

div.p: A. They laid it in a new cart, they tooke two milch kine and ſhut their calues at home, then they tyed the kine to the cart, and they went ſtraight to Bethſhemeſh, and kept one path till they came to the field of Ioſhua at Bethſhemeſh, where they ſtood ſtill.

p.hi: Q. What did the inhabitants of Bethſhemeſh?

div.p:
A. They reioyced, and the Leuites tooke downe the arke, and the cheſt wherein the iewels of gold were, and ſet them
vpon a great ſtone, and claue the wood of the cart, and offered the kine for a burnt offering vnto the Lord.
Q What befell then?
A. The Lord ſlew fifty thouſand threeſcore and ten men of the inhabitants of Bethſhemeſh, becauſe they had looked in the arke of God.
Q What became of the arke then?
chapter 7 A. The men of Kiriathiearim came and tooke it.

p.hi: Q. What did they with it?

div.p: A. They brought it into the houſe of Abinadab in the hill, and ſanctified Eleazar to keepe the arke.
Q. How long abode the arke in the houſe of Abinadab?
A. Twentie yeare.
Q. When Eli was dead, who ſucceeded him?
A. Samuel.

p.hi: Q. How many things muſt be conſidered of him?

div.p: A. His birth, education, calling, and his acts.

p.hi: Q. What doth the Holy Ghoſt ſet downe concerning his birth?

div.p: A. He was borne of a barren woman, who begged him of the Lord by prayer. chap. 1.

p.hi: Q. Who was his father?

div.p: A. Elkanah?

p.hi: Q. Who was his mother?

div.p: A. Hannah.
Q. Where was he brought vp?
A. In the tabernacle.

p.hi: Q. Who called him.

div.p: A. God called him thrice in one night. chap. 3.4.
Q. How many offices hed he?
A. Three: for as he was called thrice, ſo he had three offices: a iudge, a prieſt, and a prophet.

p.hi:
Q. VVhat chiefe things are
recorded of him?

div.p: A. He annointed Saul, cap. 10. he cauſed him to ſlay Agag the King of Ameleck. c. 15. hee annointed Dauid, cap. 16. and theſe are his acts of peace.

p.hi: Q. What were his acts of war?

div.p: A. He ouercame the Philiſtims. chap. 7.

p.hi: Q. What gouernement had the children of Iſrael after Iudges?

div.p: chapter 8 A. Kings.

p.hi: Q. How fell it out that they had kings?

div.p: chapter 10 A. Becauſe Samuels ſonnes, Ioel and Abiah walked not in their fathers waies, but peruerted iudgement, therefore they deſired a king.

p.hi: Q. How many yeares did Samuel iudge Iſrael?

div.p: A. Twentie yeares.

p.hi: Q. How many kings raignes are ſet downe in this booke?

div.p: A. Two: Sauls, and Dauids.
Q. Who was firſt King?
A. Saul.

p.hi: Q. Who annointed him?

div.p: A. Samuel, for thither he wēt to ſeeke his fathers aſſes.
Q. How many ſignes had he to confirme his annointing?
A. Three: 1. at Rahels ſepulcher: 2. at the plaine of Tabor: 3. at the hill of God: where finding a company of Prophets he propheſied, cha. 9.10. & 19. chap.
Q. Where was he choſen?
A. At Miſpah by lot, chap. 10.
Q. How many principall things muſt we conſider in Sauls raigne?
A. Two: his good and his bad deedes.

p.hi: Q. What were his good deeds?

div.p:
chapter 11 A. He fought the Lords bartell: he deliuered the inhabitants
of Iabeſh frō the Ammonites: he ouerthrew the Amalekites and Philiſtims.

p.hi: Q. What were his euill deeds?

div.p: chapter 15 A. He tooke on him the Pricſts office: he ſpared Agag and the beſt things: he perſecuted Dauid. 18. he ſlew the Lords prieſts. 21. and he conſnlted with witches, chap. 28.

p.hi: Q. How was he plagued?

div.p: A. He was reiected and Dauid elected: he was vexed with an euill ſpirit: his two ſonnes were ſlaine by the Philiſtims, & he ſlew himſelfe, chap. 31.

p.hi: Q. Who was high Prieſt?

div.p: A. Abimeleck the ſonne of Ahitub.

p.hi: Q. Who ſucceeded Saul in the kingdome?

div.p: A. Dauid.

p.hi: Q. What principall things are to be conſidered of him?

div.p: A. His calling and his acts.
Q. How many things muſt we conſider in his calling?
chapter 16 A. Three: 1. who called him? God: 2. by whom was hee called? by Samuel. 3. frō whence was he called? from keeping his fathers ſheepe.

p.hi: Q. How are the acts of Dauid deuided?

div.p: A. Into his actes in Sauls time, and his acts after Sauls death.
Q. Whatwere his acts in Sauls time?

A. He ſlew a Lyon and a Beare: he mitigated Sauls furie with his harpe: he ſlew Gokah, chapter 17. he ſlewe 300. Philiſtims for 200. fore-skinnes, for which he was made the Kings ſonne in lawe. He was preferred before Saul of the Virgins: he was perſecuted by Saul, 18.
chap. He fled to Nob and did eate the ſhewbread: 21. chapt. He fled to Gath and there hee did counterfeit himſelfe mad. 21. c. he cut off the lap of Sauls garment: he tooke away the ſpeare and a pot of water that ſtood at Sauls head. chap, 26. he deſtroed the Amalekites. chap. 30.

div.head: II. SAMVEL.
div.p: Q. What must we conſider of Dauid after Sauls death?
A. His acts after he was made king of Iſrael, and his acts when he ruled ouer Iudah onely.

p.hi: Q. What were his acts when he ruled ouer Iudah?

div.p:
